results.title: C.I.A.: the secret files
results.brief_description: This made for television documentary focuses on the covert operations of the CIA (Central Intelligence Agency) of the United States, using an array of interviews with former agents, recreations, and historical footage. Divided into six episodes, each segment focuses on a different aspect of the organisation’s history. “Berlin cowboys” Dissects the many undercover operations in circulation after WW2 in Berlin, when the Americans were determined to protect Western Europe from the spread of Communism from the East. In the 1950s, Berlin was the spy capital of the world, and CIA officers were in the front line, competing for information and trying to win the propaganda wars being fought with the Russians. Also addresses the building of the Berlin Wall. “Hi tech, low cunning” Advanced technology, such as cameras in spy planes, aided the CIA in the clandestine collecting of vital information. To gain invaluable information on Soviet missiles and weapons capacity, the CIA started using air balloons, which were easily shot down, but these were soon replaced by the U2 aeroplanes, which were superseded by satellites. “Hidden persuaders” Fearing that the powerful and popular Communist party would win, the CIA sought to undermine the Italian elections of the 1950s. Their methods included poster propaganda, circulating footage of Communists destroying Catholic churches and letters from Italian-Americans deriding Communism. The CIA was also seriously concerned about the Communist alignment of Indonesia’s President Sukarno; their methods to undermine him included circulating a ‘blue’ movie of him (or rather an actor who shared his likeness) making love to a white woman. “Phoenix rising” Using methods such as torture, kidnapping and assassination, the CIA sought to undermine the command structure of the Viet Cong during the Vietnam War. An incredibly brutal chapter in the organisation’s history. “Executive action” This episode concerns actions taken in Cuba, with the intention of removing Fidel Castro from power. Examines the fiasco which was the “Bay of Pigs”, the innumerable assassination attempts on Castro’s life, and various operations conducted with a view to undermine Castro’s power. These schemes included sabotage, and manipulation of the sugar market in the hope of ruining the Cuban economy. Also examines the capturing and execution of Che Guevera in Bolivia. Because Castro was linked to Chile’s democratically elected President Allende, the CIA sought to incite a coup, removing Allende from power by any means necessary. After Watergate and against the backdrop of the anti-war movement, the CIA was under scrutiny and consequently brought under Congressional control. “Moving targets” Final episode looks at the CIA activities in the 1980s and 1990s - Nicaragua, Iran, the Iran-Contra scandal and changes wrought within the CIA. Some scenes of torture and murder, particularly in the “Phoenix Rising” segment, may disturb.

results.title: C.F. [Cystic fibrosis]
results.brief_description: We meet children dealing with the common, inherited condition Cystic Fibrosis and they guide us through their particular experience. Also explains how the condition is inherited and passed on from one generation to the next.
results.description: We meet children dealing with the common, inherited condition Cystic Fibrosis and they guide us through their particular experience. Also explains how the condition is inherited and passed on from one generation to the next.

results.title: C'noe
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and John Shaw
results.brief_description: C’Noe shows us the many moods of one of Australia’s most spectacular rivers, which is located in Australia’s capital, Canberra, the Murrumbidgee. Dynamic rapids contrast sharply with dawn’s calm and misty waters. Canoeing and kayaking are shown. We see the “spirit of the river” in human form as he silently observes the friendly intruders. When his river is again alone he joins it in his own traditional style.

results.title: Byzantium: the lost empire
results.brief_description: A detailed and beautifully filmed exploration of the rise and fall of the legendary Byzantine Empire. Filmed in four segments, each covering a specific chapter of Byzantine history. ‘Building the Dream’ discusses how the birth of Byzantium evolved from the movement away from the pagan to the Christian with the Emperor Constantine and the new centre of the Holy Roman Empire to the east in Constantinople. ‘Heaven and Earth’ considers how Byzantium’s use of religious imagery eventually led to the period of Iconoclasm, and how the rise of Islam influenced the city. ‘Envy of the World’ shows how the religious fervour of the Holy Crusades nearly stripped Byzantium of its riches, and ‘Forever and Ever’ discusses the decline of the city and the cultural and spiritual heritage it has left behind.

results.title: Bypass: the story of a patient
results.creator_credit: Elkind Productions and David H. Elkind
results.brief_description: The true story of a heart patient from the advanced stages of his disease where coronary bypass surgery is his only alternative. The surgery is shown as is his convalescence. The film gives viewers a firsthand look at what is involved in bypass surgery and helps to alleviate fears.

results.title: Bylines
results.brief_description: A program that looks inside the Sydney Morning Herald and the staff who put the paper together. “Bylines” takes the audience from the early arrival of the Chief of Staff, through the daily drama of leaks, phone tappings and piracy on the high seas to the convoy of trucks heading into the night with the first edition.

results.title: Bygone Britain: the nation on film
results.creator_credit: Byambasuren Davaa, Allan Follett and George Lillington
results.brief_description: A historical glimpse of Britain using archival film from a collection of old film clips from widely different sources which represents and reflects some of the long forgotten images of life in Britain from the early 1930’s to the 1960’s. Includes footage of Britain in wartime, royal visits, traditional fairs and other celebrations of a bygone era. Most of the footage comes from amateur filmmakers around Great Britain. Narrated by Chris Champion.

results.title: Bye bye Birdie
results.creator_credit: Kohlmar-Sidney Productions, Columbia Pictures, Fred Kohlmar and George Sidney
results.brief_description: When a singer is drafted, a songwriter and his girlfriend decide to capitalize on the event. On national TV, Conrad Birdie will sing a song to a lucky teenager. Cast includes Janet Leigh, Dick Van Dyke, Ann-Margret, Maureen Stapleton, Bobby Rydell, Jesse Pearson and Ed Sullivan as himself. Based upon the play “Bye, bye, Birdie”, book by Michael Stewart with music and lyrics by Charles Strouse and Lee Adams.

results.title: By the seats of their pants
results.brief_description: When pilot Dick Scobee blasted off aboard the ill-fated Challenger space shuttle, he took with him a unique piece of Australia’s aviation history: a rib from Bert Hinkler’s glider. As Dick’s widow June recounts this same piece was miraculously recovered floating in the ocean amongst the Challenger debris. This programme is a fascinating look at Australia’s aviators. From pioneers such as Sir Charles Kingsford Smith, Charles Ulm and Lores Bonney, through to the pilots of both World Wars and Vietnam, to the barnstorming antics of today’s airmen and women. Experience the thrills of cattle mustering by helicopter in Australia’s wild outback, spectacular aerobatics in a rugged Pitt Special, the life-saving endeavours of the Royal Flying Doctor Service and low-level manoevres by cropduster adventurers. It is a first-hand account from the pilots who were and still are flying ‘by the seats of their pants’.
